Re ''Fateful Voice of a Generation Still Drowns Out Real Science'' (Findings, June 5): John Tierney joins an odd, dissonant chorus of cavilers who have chosen to disparage if not completely dismiss the legacy of Rachel Carson. Although we live in a time of unprecedented climate change, ecological devastation and species extinction, Tierney and his ilk critique Carson for supposed miscalculations regarding DDT.

In majestic and captivating prose, Carson notified the readers of ''Silent Spring'' that humans do not stand apart from the land, air and water. This clarion call to eco-awareness sounded 45 years ago has gone largely unheeded and thus we are today witness to precipitous environmental degradation. Those like Tierney who choose to minimize Carson's prophetic insight demonstrate a stunning capacity for crass indifference and ignorance.

John Tierney lauds agricultural expert I. L. Baldwin for his analysis of the ''costs and benefits'' of pesticide use in a 1962 review of ''Silent Spring,'' while condemning Carson's use of ''rhetoric.'' Yet Tierney forgets that cost-benefit analysis only gained currency in the United States when it became politically necessary to hold technical experts accountable for their decisions during the economic depression of the 1930s.

Similarly, when William Ruckelshaus introduced formal risk assessment at the E.P.A. in 1983, he was responding to the need for better communication with a public whose concerns had been raised in part by Carson's book. ''Silent Spring'' should be seen as a watershed event in the relationship between scientists, policy makers and the public -- one that has made debates over environmental policies more, not less, rational.
